results.process_description:
In a healthcare facility, the patient scheduling process begins when a patient contacts the reception desk to book an appointment with a specialist. 
    The receptionist verifies the patient's information, including insurance details and medical history, 
    before checking the specialist's availability on the electronic health record (EHR) system. If a suitable time is found, 
    the appointment is set, and the patient is informed about pre-appointment procedures, such as fasting or medication adjustments. 
    Confirmation calls or texts are sent to the patient 24 hours before the appointment. If the patient needs to reschedule or cancel, 
    the receptionist updates the appointment in the system and offers alternative dates.

workarounds.text: As a receptionist, when the EHR system is slow or down, I use a paper logbook or spreadsheet to temporarily track appointments to avoid delays and keep the schedule orderly.

assessment.explaination: Using a paper logbook or spreadsheet when the EHR system is down directly relates to the appointment scheduling process and helps maintain scheduling continuity.

llm_judge_domain_relevance.assessment_explaination: Using a paper logbook or spreadsheet when the EHR system is down directly relates to the appointment scheduling process and helps maintain scheduling continuity.

workarounds.text: As a receptionist, when patients provide incomplete or unclear insurance information, I call the insurance provider directly during the scheduling call to quickly verify coverage and reduce appointment cancellations.

assessment.explaination: Calling the insurance provider during scheduling to verify unclear insurance information is part of verifying patient information to reduce cancellations, which fits the described process.

llm_judge_domain_relevance.assessment_explaination: Calling the insurance provider during scheduling to verify unclear insurance information is part of verifying patient information to reduce cancellations, which fits the described process.

workarounds.text: As a receptionist, when specialist availability is limited, I keep a separate informal list of potential cancellation or emergency slots to offer patients faster alternatives without waiting for the official system update.

assessment.explaination: Maintaining an informal list of cancellation or emergency slots helps manage limited specialist availability and offers alternative scheduling options consistent with the domain.

llm_judge_domain_relevance.assessment_explaination: Maintaining an informal list of cancellation or emergency slots helps manage limited specialist availability and offers alternative scheduling options consistent with the domain.

workarounds.text: As a receptionist, when patients have difficulty understanding pre-appointment instructions, I create and hand out printed checklists to ensure they clearly know what to do before the visit.

assessment.explaination: Providing printed checklists for pre-appointment instructions assists in ensuring patients understand preparatory procedures, directly supporting the pre-appointment communication step.

llm_judge_domain_relevance.assessment_explaination: Providing printed checklists for pre-appointment instructions assists in ensuring patients understand preparatory procedures, directly supporting the pre-appointment communication step.

workarounds.text: As a receptionist, when confirmation calls or texts cannot be delivered due to communication barriers, I ask family members or emergency contacts for alternative ways to confirm appointments and reduce no-shows.

assessment.explaination: Contacting family members or emergency contacts when confirmation calls or texts fail addresses communication barriers in appointment confirmation, which is part of the scheduling process.

llm_judge_domain_relevance.assessment_explaination: Contacting family members or emergency contacts when confirmation calls or texts fail addresses communication barriers in appointment confirmation, which is part of the scheduling process.
